content: China’s Leader Says He Is ‘Worried’ Over U.S. Treasuries BEIJING — The Chinese prime minister, Wen Jiabao, spoke in unusually blunt terms on Friday about the “safety” of China’s $1 trillion investment in American government debt, the world’s largest such holding, and urged the Obama administration to offer assurances that the securities would maintain their value. Speaking ahead of a meeting of finance ministers and bankers this weekend near London to lay the groundwork for next month’s Group of 20 summit meeting of the nations with the 20 largest economies, Mr. Wen said that he was “worried” about China’s holdings of United States Treasury bonds and other debt, and that China was watching economic developments in the United States closely. Full article at > >http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/14/world/asia/14china.html?th&emc=th This could be big trouble in the very near future.

content: If China Stops Lending Us Money, Look Out China is the single largest foreign holder of U.S. Treasurys. The money it lends to the Feds finances our significant budget deficits. (Americans have been paying about $450 billion a year in interest on the national credit card; without that debt to pay off, personal income taxes could be almost 40 percent lower.) But in Beijing on Friday, Premier Wen Jiabao told reporters that he was worried about the U.S. becoming something of a, well, deadbeat. "We have made a huge amount of loans to the United States. Of course we are concerned about the safety of our assets. To be honest, I'm a little bit worried," Wen said. "I would like to call on the United States to honor its words, stay a credible nation and ensure the safety of Chinese assets." What China's premier may be worried about is the possibility of the U.S. running up so much debt -- the projected 2009 deficit is $1.75 trillion -- that it may not be able or willing to pay it back without devaluing the currency. (If that happens, hello, inflation!) Read full article here > >http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2009/03/13/business/econwatch/entry4864398.shtml

content: The devaluing of the currency is a no brainer. China knows where this is heading and is giving fare warning. Inflation will hit us a lot harder than the 3%-5% of the past decade. Right now it is close to zero, but that is due to the fact that none of the new currency that they have been printing has found its way into the economy. Once the banks start lending again it will open up the floodgates. But, the Fed will increase the discount window rate to counteract. This will in turn raise the interest rates that the banks will offer. So, if you want to take advantage of good rates, then get your loans now if you can. But, keep in mind that the currency will lose value at an accelerated rate in the next few years. So, you better be able to make that payment and have enough to live on, too.
